paragraphs.text:
%md
# About This Lab
**Objective:** Become familiar with simple RDD operations. Load a simple text file into 
Resilient Distributed Dataset (RDD) and display the contents. Then create two new RDDs
and use transformations to union them and remove duplicates.
**Exercise files** 
    Exercise directory: /home/training/training_materials/devsh/exercises/rdds
    Data (local): /home/training/training_materials/devsh/data/frostroad.txt
                  /home/training/training_materials/devsh/data/makes1.txt  makes2.txt
**Successful outcome:**
**Before you begin:**
**Related lessons:** RDD Overview

---

msg.data:

Data (local): /home/training/training_materials/devsh/data/frostroad.txt
              /home/training/training_materials/devsh/data/makes1.txt  makes2.txt

# Setup
---

The following cells allow this notebook to run without errors from top to bottom any number of times

msg.data:
Setup

The following cells allow this notebook to run without errors from top to bottom any number of times

paragraphs.title: Delete HDFS files to prevent files exist errors
paragraphs.text:
%sh

hdfs dfs -rm -r -f -skipTrash /devsh_loudacre/frostroad.txt
hdfs dfs -rm -r -f -skipTrash /devsh_loudacre/makes*.txt

paragraphs.title: Environment variable required to use SetJobGroup
paragraphs.text:
%sh

PYSPARK_PIN_THREAD=true

paragraphs.title: Retrieve the Spark Context
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

sc= spark.sparkContext

%md
# Lab
---

Take note of the various available operations.

paragraphs.title: 4 - Count the lines in your RDD
paragraphs.text: %pyspark

%md
The count operation causes the RDD to be materialized (created and populated).
The number of lines (23) should be displayed, for example:
```pyspark
Out[2]: 23(Python) 
```
or
```spark
res1: Long = 23(Scala)
```
Call the collect operation to return all data in the RDD to the Spark driver. 
Take note of the type of the return value; in Python will be a list of strings, and in Scala it will be an array of strings.

**Note:** collect returns the entire set of data. This is convenient for very small RDDs like this one, but be careful using collect for more typical large sets of data.

paragraphs.text:

# Solution
---

msg.data: Solution

paragraphs.text:
%md
### Review the API Documentation for RDD Operations

Review the API docs for the RDD class (which is in the Python module pyspark, and the Scala package org.apache.spark.rdd). 
Take note of the various available operations.

msg.data:
Review the API Documentation for RDD Operations

Review the API docs for the RDD class (which is in the Python module pyspark, and the Scala package org.apache.spark.rdd).
Take note of the various available operations.

paragraphs.text:
%md
#### RDD
Resilient Distributed Dataset (RDD) is a fundamental data structure of Spark. It is an immutable distributed 
collection of objects. The HDFS data blocks are immutable. The HDFS data blocks are distributed across the 
cluster. In Spark a RDD is divided into logical partitions, each partition may be computed on different nodes 
of the cluster. A Spark logical partition is physically a HDFS data block.

msg.data:
RDD

Resilient Distributed Dataset (RDD) is a fundamental data structure of Spark. It is an immutable distributed
collection of objects. The HDFS data blocks are immutable. The HDFS data blocks are distributed across the
cluster. In Spark a RDD is divided into logical partitions, each partition may be computed on different nodes
of the cluster. A Spark logical partition is physically a HDFS data block.

paragraphs.text:
%md
### Read and Display Data from a Text File

msg.data: Read and Display Data from a Text File

paragraphs.title: 1 - Read /home/training/training_materials/devsh/data/frostroad.txt
paragraphs.text:
%sh

cat /home/training/training_materials/devsh/data/frostroad.txt

msg.data:
Two roads diverged in a yellow wood,
And sorry I could not travel both
And be one traveler, long I stood
And looked down one as far as I could
To where it bent in the undergrowth;

Then took the other, as just as fair,
And having perhaps the better claim,
Because it was grassy and wanted wear;
Though as for that the passing there
Had worn them really about the same,

And both that morning equally lay
In leaves no step had trodden black.
Oh, I kept the first for another day!
Yet knowing how way leads on to way,
I doubted if I should ever come back.

I shall be telling this with a sigh
Somewhere ages and ages hence:
Two roads diverged in a wood, and I--
I took the one less traveled by,
And that has made all the difference.

paragraphs.text:
%md
Review the simple text file you will be using. The file is located at 
`/home/training/training_materials/devsh/data/frostroad.txt`.

msg.data:

/home/training/training_materials/devsh/data/frostroad.txt.

paragraphs.title: 2 - Upload the text file to HDFS directory /devsh_loudacre
paragraphs.text:
%sh
hdfs dfs -rm -r -skipTrash /devsh_loudacre/frostroad.txt
hdfs dfs -put /home/training/training_materials/devsh/data/frostroad.txt /devsh_loudacre

msg.data: rm: `/devsh_loudacre/frostroad.txt': No such file or directory

paragraphs.text:
%md
Load the `frostroad.txt` file into hdfs.

msg.data: Load the frostroad.txt file into hdfs.

paragraphs.title: 3 - Define an RDD based on the frostroad.txt text file
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

myRDD = sc.textFile("/devsh_loudacre/frostroad.txt")

%md
Define a RDD, `myRDD`, and load the text file `frostroad.txt`
Use the spark context `textFile` function to load unstructured data, such as web logs.

msg.data:
Define a RDD, myRDD, and load the text file frostroad.txt
Use the spark context textFile function to load unstructured data, such as web logs.

paragraphs.title: 4 - Count the lines in your RDD
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

sc.setJobGroup("Working with RDDs","Count the lines in your RDD")
myRDD.count()

%md
Spark has not yet read the file. It will not do so until you perform an action on the RDD.
Try counting the number of elements in the RDD using the count action:

msg.data:
Spark has not yet read the file. It will not do so until you perform an action on the RDD.
Try counting the number of elements in the RDD using the count action:

paragraphs.text:
%md
Spark uses lazy execution, transformations do not manipulate data, only actions 
result in data manipulation. The term materialize is used when data is created and populated.

The count operation causes the RDD to be materialized.
The number of lines (23) should be displayed, for example:
```pyspark
Out[2]: 23(Python) 
```
or
```spark
res1: Long = 23(Scala)
```
Call the collect operation to return all data in the RDD to the Spark driver. 
Take note of the type of the return value; in Python will be a list of strings, and in Scala it will be an array of strings.

**Note:** collect returns the entire set of data. This is convenient for very small RDDs like this one, but be careful using collect for more typical large sets of data.

msg.data:
Spark uses lazy execution, transformations do not manipulate data, only actions
result in data manipulation. The term materialize is used when data is created and populated.

The count operation causes the RDD to be materialized.
The number of lines (23) should be displayed, for example:

Out[2]: 23(Python)

or

res1: Long = 23(Scala)

Call the collect operation to return all data in the RDD to the Spark driver.
Take note of the type of the return value; in Python will be a list of strings, and in Scala it will be an array of strings.

Note: collect returns the entire set of data. This is convenient for very small RDDs like this one, but be careful using collect for more typical large sets of data.

paragraphs.title: 5 - Collect your RDD
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

sc.setJobGroup("Working with RDDs","Collect your RDD")
lines = myRDD.collect()

msg.data:
Return all of the data by using the collect function. Take note of the type of the return value;
in Python it will be a list of strings, and in Scala it will be an array of strings.

paragraphs.title: 6 - Display the contents of the collected data by looping through the collection
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

for line in lines: print(line)

msg.data:
Two roads diverged in a yellow wood,
And sorry I could not travel both
And be one traveler, long I stood
And looked down one as far as I could
To where it bent in the undergrowth;

Then took the other, as just as fair,
And having perhaps the better claim,
Because it was grassy and wanted wear;
Though as for that the passing there
Had worn them really about the same,

And both that morning equally lay
In leaves no step had trodden black.
Oh, I kept the first for another day!
Yet knowing how way leads on to way,
I doubted if I should ever come back.

I shall be telling this with a sigh
Somewhere ages and ages hence:
Two roads diverged in a wood, and I--
I took the one less traveled by,
And that has made all the difference.

paragraphs.title: 10 - Repeat the previous steps to create and display an RDD called makes2RDD based on the second file, /devsh_loudacre/makes2.txt
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

makes2RDD = sc.textFile("/devsh_loudacre/makes2.txt")
sc.setJobGroup("Working with RDDs","Display the contents of the makes2RDD")
for make in makes2RDD.collect(): print(make)

paragraphs.title: Delete the Livy session
paragraphs.text:
%sh

sessionId=$(curl -s localhost:8998/sessions | jq '.sessions[0].id')
curl -s localhost:8998/sessions/$sessionId -X DELETE

msg.data: {"msg":"Session 'null' not found."}

paragraphs.title: Additional resources
paragraphs.text:
%md
We hope you've enjoyed this lab. Below are additional resources that you should find useful:

1. [Cloudera Tutorials](http://cloudera.com/tutorials.html) are your natural next step where you can explore Spark in more depth.
2. [Cloudera Community](https://community.cloudera.com) is a great resource for questions and answers on Spark, Data Analytics/Science, and many more Big Data topics.
3. [Apache Spark Documentation](https://spark.apache.org/documentation.html) - official Spark documentation.
4. [Apache Zeppelin Project Home Page](https://zeppelin.apache.org) - official Zeppelin web site.
